div1.p: Redd discusses Carter's estate and mentions the appreciation of his work during a Kiwanis Club function.

div1.head: Letter from H. Carter Redd to Laura Armistead Carter, December 2, 1925
div1.opener:
Miscl-
Carter Redd
Life Insurance
Waiver-
SAMUEL R. CARTER
WM. E. CRAWFORD
H. CARTER REDD
COMMISSIONERS IN CHANCERY, CIRCUIT COURT
OF HANOVER COUNTY.
CARTER, CRAWFORD & REDD
ATTORNEYS-AT-LAW
700 TRAVELERS BUILDING
RICHMOND, VA., December 2, 1925.
&
Ennion Williams' speech
about Father
Dear Laura:
div1.p:
I have your letter of the first and am extremely sorry
to know that you are feeling so badly, but I do not wonder at
it. The remarkable thing is that you have held up as long as
you have. I hope you will soon be feeling all right and can
get to work on your book as I know you are anxious to do. Aunt
Mary told me that the Rockefellers also wished you to write a
life of Uncle Henry. I, too, hope that you will be able to do
this.

On last Monday night at our Kiwanis Club in Ashland, we
had a “Health Night” and Dr. Ennion G. Williams, Health Commis-
sioner of Virginia, made the speech of the evening, in which he
referred to Gorgas and his work on the Panama Canal. He told
how Yellow Fever had been practically stamped out, and then he
stopped and said to the audience: “It may be interesting for
you to know that while Gorgas was an administrator, he only did
the things that he was told to do by Dr. Henry R. Carter, a na-
tive of your County, who was a short time ago laid to rest in
your cemetery here. Dr. Carter was probably the most celebrat-
ed scientest the world has ever known. He mapped out the work
which Gorgas did. Dr. Carter was the moving spirit, who said
what was to be done, and he, Gorgas, carried it out.” He also
referred to Uncle Henry's originating the ideas later carried
out by Reed in the Yellow Fever work.

Coming back to yourself, I hope you will take every pre-
caution possible and necessary to bring yourself back to your
normal health again. You should do this not only for your own
sake, but for us; and there is a big work before you which I
pray you may be “physically fit” to do. I know that you are
fitted in every other way.

I got the letter from Mr. Hayne with a $500.00 note pay-
able to your order. I will have to advance this out of Uncle
Henry's estate as I have only about $125.00 in bank to your cre-
dit at this time. Shall I send this note on to you or keep it
in my safe? In this connection, have you not the other notes
given by Mr. Hayne, if any? If you have, and they are payable
to Uncle Henry, they should be appraised as a part of his estate.
If you have, and they are payable to you, then Uncle Henry's es-
tate is not interested in them and would not have to include them
in the appraisal. Have you any other notes, bonds or obligations
of any kind due to Uncle Henry's Estate?

I shall bear in mind Ed's expense and keep the money
on hand to meet it. I got $100.00 through James Martin, and
he writes me that there is some more coming from the Govern-
ment later. He also said that all of the Portsmouth lots are
sold; therefore, I did not have any taxes to pay in Ports-
mouth this year and am awaiting the receipt of the further
payment of Martin when collected by him, unless he will send
it direct to you. I, like you, am afraid that he will have
to pay it to me because the Government will refuse to pay it
otherwise.

There are so many things we can think of which would
have saved trouble if we had only known before. When I went
to the hospital, I signed my name to checks, and showed Jen-
nie where they were with directions that if anything happen-
ed to me, to cash those checks immediately. Thus, she would
have in her own name all money that I had on deposit immedi-
ately available without waiting for her qualification and the
giving of bond to cover it & without the incidental legal red
tape. She of course, went right up in the air and did not
want to hear anything of the kind. I told her that I expect-
ed to come back (as I did do), but she would find the simple
little things that I had mentioned a great convenience and
help and also a saving of money and time if anything should
happen, and that such precautions did not hasten my passing
out one moment, as she has since found out.

I am sending you herein a letter from the insurance
company and a waiver for you to sign, after which I would be
glad if you would send it on to Ed to sign. In further ex-
planation of the letter, it seems that the insurance company
is not sure of its position in regard to one of the policies,
to-wit, the one in the old Washington Company, and wishes
waivers by the heirs of Laura E. Carter (as a double precau-
tion, I think) before they will pay the money over to me. I
hope, upon getting these waivers, that I can then close up
this insurance matter. It is hard luck that the first compa-
ny in which Uncle Henry took a policy went bad and the one tak-
ing that over went bad, and that the other company in which he
took a policy also went band, and that the Metropolitan took
over both. The Metropolitan, however, has made good with
them and has informed me that there would be a little over
$11,000.00 coming to the estate from these policies.
div1.closer: Affectionately yours, H.C. Redd HCR: CEH
